Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the College of Science Scholars Program, California State Polytechnic University, Pomona (Cal Poly Pomona), an Hispanic Serving Institution, is leveraging the infrastructure of its Science Educational Enhancement Services (SEES) to increase the number of academically successful, financially disadvantaged STEM students in the College of Science. By the end of the project, Cal Poly Pomona will have awarded approximately 86 scholarships to academically successful, financially disadvantaged junior/senior STEM students with the majority of them having graduated with a B.S. degree and transitioned into the workforce.

The SEES supportive community counsels its members to effectively navigate the campus while providing opportunities for academic support, career networking, and community outreach. Activities of the College of Science Scholars Program include:
- advising provided by SEES faculty;
- peer-led support through Academic Excellence Workshops;
- access to a study center for tutoring and computer facilities; and
- professional development and workforce links through research apprenticeships, mentoring and cooperative education programs.

Through these strategic activities, scholarship recipients are developing strong relationships with faculty and becoming efficient in their time to graduation. When these scholars graduate and join the workforce, they will be role models reflecting the highly diverse Cal Poly Pomona campus (approximately 35% of the students at Cal Poly Pomona are members of populations underrepresented in STEM fields) as well as exemplary representatives of Southern California.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this project was to grant scholarships that provide students with the financial flexibility to focus on becoming a dynamic community of scholars within the College of Science through academic support services, career counseling and job placement, community building, internships, conferences, research opportunities, mentoring, and seminar invitations.

During the program, 118 scholarships (that lasted from 1-3 years) were granted to 72 individual students who were STEM majors that showed academic promise and financial need from the College of Science. 

 

Each cohort of scholars participated in quarterly workshops and networking luncheons. In the workshops the scholars focused on developing strong statements of purpose (fall) and crafting winning resumes (winter). In the networking luncheon the scholars debated and discussed current STEM issues in the news as a chance to connect on a professional level and gain more exposure to how their fellow scholars diagnosed and engage in critical thought. The workshops were collaborative events that were attend by the scholars from four different campus programs to exposure the participants to various ideas and create a community of university scholars. Prior to each Fall quarter, the PI met with each scholar individually to discuss their individual academic progress and undergraduate research opportunities. It was during this initial meeting that the scholars were able to identify personal goals that could be accomplished during the academic year. The final luncheon provided an opportunity to congratulate the graduates and learn about their future employment or plans to pursue advanced degrees. 

In total, 98.6% of the program participants graduated with a STEM degree. 100% of the program participants who finished the program in good standing graduated with a STEM degree.
